item.title: How to Get the Deathmask of Nirmitruq in Diablo 4
item.description:
The Deathmask of Nirmitruq is a truly unique helmet for Rogues in Diablo 4 . It opens up a risky but rewarding playstyle that can be very powerful if players manage to play properly, and it's incredibly fun to use if you prefer playing Rogue as a melee class.

Getting a Deathmask of Nirmitruq is fairly simple, and depending on what Rogue build you're using in Diablo 4 , you should be able to get one in a flash. Here are all the options you have to get this Unique helmet.

Where to Get the Deathmask of Nirmitruq in Diablo 4

Players can get the Deathmask of Nirmitruq by opening the treasure hoards of the Beast in the Ice and Urivar . The former can be found in the Glacial Fissure due south of Kyovashad, while the latter is in the Fields of Judgment west of Kichuk in northeastern Kurast.

Both are relatively easy to beat for Rogues, especially if you're using a build with high burst damage like Frost Rapid Fire Rogue using Scoundrel's Kiss and Skyhunter . Farm these bosses on Torment 1 until you can comfortably beat them on higher difficulties.

Belial's Hoard

As you're farming Urivar and the Beast in the Ice, you might get invaded by Belial . Beating him there will yield another set of boss drops. Also, he'll drop some Betrayer's Husks, which can be used to open his hoard in the Palace of the Deceiver lair.

You can fight Belial for a chance of getting drops from a boss of your choice. Belial does not have his own loot table â€” instead, he'll drop loot from whatever boss you choose before starting his fight.

What Does Deathmask of Nirmitruq Do?

This Unique helmet lets players continue using Flurry even without Energy. In exchange, the mask will drain its wearer's health, but at the same time, Flurry will hit faster and harder.

The Deathmask of Nirmitruq in Diablo 4 can easily get players killed if they aren't careful, but Rogues have a number of tools to keep themselves alive outside of keeping themselves high on Life. Barrier effects are the first to come to mind.

Rogues can easily get one-shot on Torment 1 and above even if they have full health, so players are often forced to find survivability elsewhere. Situations like these make Life an expendable resource, which means a clever Rogue build in Diablo 4 can easily take advantage of Deathmask of Nirmitruq without having to worry about its Life cost.

item.title: GTA 6 Fans May Want to Keep an Eye on August 7
item.description:
Grand Theft Auto 6 fans may want to circle August 7 on their calendars, as Rockstar Games' parent company, Take-Two Interactive, has confirmed its next earnings call will take place on that date. While any significant updates surrounding Grand Theft Auto 6 will likely come from Rockstar, Take-Two Interactive CEO Strauss Zelnick has been known to discuss the ongoing development of the title during these calls, which means new details could be shared next month.

It's now been over two months since Rockstar shocked the world with Grand Theft Auto 6 's second trailer. Its release also came alongside an updated website for the game and over 70 new screenshots, which have kept fans occupied for the last eight weeks. But after analyzing every tiny detail of the trailer, recreating standout moments in other games, and discovering every easter egg there is to find, fans are eager to know when the next trailer or info drop surrounding the game will arrive. While it may not be anything massive, a small development update could be shared in the coming weeks.

Take-Two Interactive, parent company of Rockstar Games, has announced it will be holding a new quarterly earnings call on Thursday, August 7. These calls are usually hosted by the company's CEO, Strauss Zelnick, and last for approximately one hour. During the call, Take-Two will update its investors with news and details on the company's upcoming titles. While many will be well aware that Take-Two is the owner of Rockstar, the company also owns Mafia publisher 2K Games, mobile giant Zynga, and many more. Alongside some possible development updates, Take-Two often updates listeners and shareholders with new sales figures for the likes of Grand Theft Auto 5 , Red Dead Redemption , and many more.

Take-Two Has Provided GTA 6 Updates in the Past

Any major news surrounding Grand Theft Auto 6 is unlikely to occur during the call, but that doesn't mean fans shouldn't tune in on August 7 for a potential development update. Take-Two CEO Strauss Zelnick regularly discusses Grand Theft Auto 6 in interviews and earnings calls, often reaffirming that the game is still on track. It's also worth noting that the first trailer for Grand Theft Auto 6 only stated that it would be released in 2025, but it was during a Take-Two earnings call that its release window was narrowed down to Fall 2025.

Of course, we now know that the Fall 2025 release window is a thing of the past, as Rockstar Games shared some disappointing news earlier this year when it announced that Grand Theft Auto 6 had been delayed. In a new statement on Twitter, the studio said that its goal is to always "try and exceed your expectations," and Grand Theft Auto 6 will be no exception to that. Rockstar went on to state that it needs the extra time to deliver the quality fans have grown to expect from the studio.

Grand Theft Auto 6 will now launch for PlayStation 5 and Xbox Series X/S on May 26, 2026.

item.title: Ghost Of Yotei's Protagonist: 6 Things We Know About Atsu
item.description:
Summary

  • Atsu is based on the vengeful Onryo mythology, seeking revenge on those who wronged her family.
  • Atsu hunts down the Yotei Six, responsible for her family's slaughter, as her primary mission.
  • Atsu, not a samurai, embraces a reputation as an infamous bounty hunter with a thirst for vengeance.

Ghost of Yotei , the hotly anticipated sequel to the critically acclaimed Ghost of Tsushima , is shaping up to be one of the best games of 2025. The good news is that developers Sucker Punch have revealed some pretty juicy details over the last few months concerning not just the setting and core gameplay, but also the sequel's brand-new protagonist, Atsu, who seems like she's going to be quite a bit different from the legendary Jin Sakai.

On the surface, it may seem as though Atsu follows the same path of the samurai as Jin did, but there's actually a lot more to this character than meets the eye and which will inevitably lead her down a very different storyline. Fans only have to wait a little longer to get their hands on Ghost of Yotei , but for those eager to learn more about Atsu and her adventure, here's what has been revealed about the fresh protagonist on the block.

6 She Is Seen As An Onryo By The People

The People Of Ezo View Atsu As A Vengeful Figure From Japanese Mythology

Anyone familiar with Japanese mythology will be well aware that ghosts and spirits are very common entities within folk stories, with one of the most prominent being the Onryo. These are considered to be vengeful or hateful ghosts who are capable of causing harm and suffering in the real world, presenting them as horror-like figures who usually take the form of women who had been wronged when they were still alive.

It's clear that Sucker Punch wanted to use the Onryo as the basis for Atsu's character, since it seems like it will directly feed into her personal journey, which primarily evolves around getting revenge on those who did her wrong. At the same time, it's also a nice way to expand on the concept of the protagonist being seen as a dangerous and almost frightening entity, similar to how Jin became seen as a ghost by the people of Tsushima in the previous game.

5 She Is Hunting Down The Yotei Six

Atsu Has A Thirst For Vengeance Against Those Who Slaughtered Her Family

Many fans were left wondering what exactly the main story of Ghost of Yotei was going to be from the announcement trailer, but Sucker Punch have made things a little clearer with the introduction of the Yotei Six. This fearsome members of this group of warriors are the ones who are responsible for slaughtering Atsu's family, and as a result, she is on a desperate mission to hunt down each and every one of them to ensure that they don't escape being punished for their crimes.

While each member of the group shares similarly styled masks and are also deadly swordmasters, everything else about them seems to be completely different, which will no doubt lead to some fascinating interactions throughout the story. In the case of Atsu, though, she will most likely simply want to cut each of them down for what they did to her loved ones as part of this grandiose revenge story.

4 She Is Returning Home After 16 Years

After Many Years, Atsu Decides It's Time To Deliver Justice

Because Atsu was still only a child when her family was taken from her, she was in no position to fight back against the gang of criminals who delivered the final blows. After 16 whole years of residing in Southern Japan, though, Atsu has returned home, now having much more combat experience under her belt and a plethora of deadly tools and weapons to help her on the mission.

This whole idea of Atsu being separated from her home for more than a decade is actually played into the gameplay itself, where players can switch between a child version of Atsu and her adult iteration with the press of a button to experience Yotei from two different perspectives. One thing is for sure: It's going to be interesting to see how the land has changed after so many years and, most importantly, what impact this time away has had on Atsu herself.

3 She Gains An Infamous Reputation

As Atsu Causes More Chaos, Her Reputation As An Onryo Grows

When Atsu spills blood, this won't go unnoticed by the people of Yotei. Considering Atsu is dead-set on bringing her family's murderers to justice, she is more than willing to slice apart anyone who stands in her way, and this will ultimately bolster her reputation as the mythical Onryo as the game goes on. So far, Sucker Punch has shown a few brief scenes that showcase how the civilians react to Atsu's actions, many of them being fearful of her underlying power and infamous reputation.

It seems that Atsu isn't going to be quite as squeaky clean as Jin initially was in Ghost of Tsushima , with her instead appearing as more of a ruthless warrior who everyone has their own opinion on. It'll definitely be intriguing to see how this reputation affects the gameplay, as it's clearly going to be a big part of the main story.

2 She Can Be A Bounty Hunter

Atsu Has No Quarrel Taking Down Those With High Prices On Their Heads

Atsu may be on a heroic mission to avenge her family, but that doesn't inherently mean that she has a crowd of people supporting her. In fact, she actually has a bounty on her head, which essentially makes her a wanted criminal. On the other hand, though, she's also capable of playing the role of bounty hunter herself by snooping out any samurai or thugs who can be brought in for some extra cash.

While defeating these kinds of enemies definitely isn't easy, considering that the majority of them have entire swarms of allies to keep them protected, Atsu is still more than willing to do what she must to earn the funds needed to complete her mission of revenge. It's going to be a lot of fun engaging in these bounty missions, but it will also be interesting to see how people respond to Atsu herself, considering that she's also a highly valuable target.

1 She Is Not A Samurai

Atsu Is A Free Spirit Who Isn't Forced To Follow The Samurai Code

By far the biggest difference between Jin and Atsu is that, while the former was a samurai struggling to stick to his code, Atsu is not a samurai at all. In fact, Sucker Punch described her as a "lone wolf mercenary," and while she's clearly more than comfortable using a sword in combat, she's also not above using dirty tactics to get an advantage over her opponents.

While this obviously opens up many new combat options, it will also result in a drastically different story considering that Atsu's moral dilemmas are going to be a lot different to Jin's. Atsu may be determined to honor the life of her family, but she isn't indebted to any kind of samurai code that may have restricted her style of fighting, as it did with the previous protagonist.

item.title: Diablo 4: How to Get & Use Betrayer's Husks
item.description:
Farming Uniques in Diablo 4 can be a pain, especially once you run out of materials for opening Lair Boss Hoards. Thankfully, Belial is here to make the grind a bit more manageable and significantly more efficient, assuming you know how Betrayer's Husks work.

Grinding for Lair Boss loot in Diablo 4 has never been easier after the system got reworked in Season 8, which changed how boss materials worked. More importantly, that season also introduced Belial as another Lair Boss. If you want to take advantage of what he provides, here's a guide on how to use Betrayer's Husks.

How to Farm Betrayer's Husks

Players can get Betrayer's Husks by beating Belial, but only if he appears after you open any of the Boss Hoards in the game. Belial won't drop any husks if you beat him in his Lair Boss Dungeon (Palace of the Deceiver in Kehjistan), so if you want to farm this Hoard key material, you'll need to farm the other Lair Bosses.

Thankfully, Belial can appear after any Lair Boss fight, so if you have tons of Hoard keys/materials for one boss, you should be able to get a decent collection of Betrayer's Husks after using them all.

While you're playing, make sure to target Tree of Whispers bounties. Doing so can earn you a ton of Malignant Hearts for Varshan, which you can use to farm other Uniques in Diablo 4 while also potentially summoning Belial.

Other potential sources of Betrayer's Husks include:

  • Kurast Undercity rewards chests (especially those empowered by Tribute of Titans).
  • Whisper Caches may also drop Betrayer's Husks.
  • Fayira in the Den sells boss summoning materials. These may include Betrayer's Husks, but if they don't, you'll at least get materials for summoning other bosses.

The base form of Belial that appears after a Lair Boss fight is fairly easy to beat, and once his health reaches zero, he will retreat. Beating him here will also reward you with a second batch of loot drops based on the Lair Boss you just defeated, essentially giving you two drops' worth of loot for one set of boss summoning materials.

Where to Use Betrayer's Husks in Diablo 4

Betrayer's Husks are used to open Belial's Hoard . However, as you've surely noticed by now, base form Belial does not cause Belial's Hoard to appear after beating him in a different boss' lair. For his specific chest to appear, you need to fight and beat him in the Palace of the Deceiver , which is found in the Amber Sands region in Kehjistan.

This is Belial's personal boss lair, and here, you'll get to fight him in his giant form. It's a callback to his original boss fight in Diablo 3 , albeit with a few different mechanics.

The cool thing about Belial and his loot is that he does not have a unique loot table . Instead, you'll get to choose which Lair Boss' loot you can get after opening Belial's Hoard. Essentially, this means that beating Belial will let you earn loot even without having to fight a specific boss or farm for specific resources, making him an extremely convenient source of the best items in the game.

As with all things Lair Boss-related, these are only applicable on Torment 1 and above.
